title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. Section 1851(g)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses a serious risk to enrolled individuals' health. The Secretary can delay termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses imminent health risks or reduces available plans in the area. The Secretary can delay termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it would significantly reduce available plans in the affected area or if the organization offers plans in nearby contract areas. The Secretary can delay termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it would reduce available plans in the affected area or if the organization offers plans in nearby contract areas without suffering financial losses. The Secretary may audit and inspect organization's books or records to determine termination impact without causing financial losses. The Secretary may end a delay in termination if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. The Secretary can end a delay in termination if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. The Medicare+Choice organization can renegotiate a new contract with the Secretary if termination is delayed, allowing them to continue coverage under a new agreement. The Medicare+Choice organization can negotiate a new contract with the Secretary to continue coverage if termination is delayed, ensuring beneficiaries are not negatively impacted. SEC. 3. Extension of initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. Amends the Social Security Act to require contracts to have a minimum term of 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Notice of termination. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require organizations to provide written notice 120 days before terminating a contract under this section. The notice must include alternatives for obtaining benefits under this title for enrolled individuals. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act now mandates organizations to give a 120-day written notice before terminating a contract. The notice must include alternative options for beneficiaries to obtain benefits under this title. The Social Security Act requires organizations to provide a 120-day written notice before terminating a contract, including details on available Medicare+Choice plans, Medicare supplemental policies, and local social service agency contact information for assistance to beneficiaries in the area. The amendment made by this section is effective immediately. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to any notice of termination provided on or after the date of enactment of this Act.
